reviews: Awesome spot to visit in Death Valley

Great views walk out onto the salt flats for awesome pictures. Lowest spot in North America. Hike up to a narrow canyon in the side of the mountain on the opposite side of the highway from the parking lot.
Beautiful and very historic movie location in Death Valley National Park. Great photo opportunities and salt findings al
Absolutely beautiful area that once hosted numerous movie settings, slat production, Borax source and much more. This is a must see if one visits Death Valley National Park.
Another Interesting DV Walk at the Badlands!

While visiting the Badlands below-sea-level sign provides a cool photo op, the best photos are achieved by walking about a mile to mile and a half out where you see the salt crystals has created some amazing patterns!

Another unique geological wonder of DV that shouldn't be missed!
Show less
Great site. Doesn't take a long time to visit.

My husband and I walked waaay out, past all the tourists to get pictures without other people in them. The salt crystals get bigger and bigger the farther you wander. Being a rare site, it's worth seeing. I think we stayed less than an hour and got some fantastic pictures.
Show less
A cool way to experience the salt flats. Several places to stop and take pictures and walk around for a closer look. Just a cool and interesting part of nature.
We love doing extremes - this is the location of the lowest point in the United States at - 281 feet below sea level ! Down on the salt flats - we get to check it off our bucket list !
Interesting area way below sea level. Be sure to look around and note the "sea level" sign high above on the mountain!

tThis was my second trip to Badwater. The first time, I was part of a photo workshop and the instructor knew exactly where to go to shoot the most stunning images of the salt crystals. As you walk down the salt path, the crystals to the left and right are unimpressive. But, if you are willing to walk further and about 1-1.5 miles, the crystals get whiter and more impressive. Still, they are not as impressive as the spot where the photo tour took us. That spot was about ½ way in between.

Also, sunset at Death Valley in late February is around 5:30pm. But if you want to get a nice sunset shot, you need to be at the park around 4:30pm since there is a mountain range to the west which will block the sun rays at 5:30pm
Show less

The blurry whiteness of the salty landscape is the first thing you will notice coming to the Badwater Basin, noted as the lowest point in North America (282 ft or 86 m below sea level). The entire place looks like snowy tracks but the temperatures can be really high here. That place is simply magical and beautiful. Taking a walk on the salt flats is like no other experience. I wish I could see that place during sunset!

Worth to see it for a quick look

I definitely recommend to see this, but I think that just quick look on this, experience the heat and take some pictures is enough. I don`t think it is worth to walk and follow the path in the middle of the valley. But that`s just my opinion :-)

This is it! The lowest place in North America. In fact 282 ft below sea level. As a proof take a look at the sign up on the mountain across the parking lot to remind yourself how deep you are. We were here in Feb and weather was perfect. Blue sky, sun and about 60 F. Take a walk into the lowland (for about half a mile out) to be right in the middle of the flats and enjoy the beautiful scenery and patterns created by the salt rocks. Feels out of this world...

the badwater basin is a interesant place for location and cultural interest. from other point of view, is a place un the middle of the desert, very hot without nothing interesting to see. you only have a parking place and a mark for a level sea. badwaters is really this two points of view.
Show less

No visit to death Valley is complete without visiting the lowest spot in the Northern hemisphere. Really cool to see way up on the cliff above your head a sign indicating sea level. Definitely worth visiting in February, probably wouldn’t want to be there in the middle of summer.
Show less

Badwater Basin, at 282 ft/86 m, is the lowest point in North America. There is a 1 mi/1.6 km trail to the edge of the salt flats, as well as a 5 mi/8 km walk to the other side of the salt flats. There is a decent-sized parking lot at the basin.

We visited the basin around noon on a Friday in November. Although it was crowded at the Badwater Basin sign with people snapping photos, not everyone takes the trail. We really enjoyed the peaceful walk to the salt flats and would have walked more had it not been so hot (86 deg F/30 deg C). At the salt flats, there are incredible panoramic views of the valley.
Show less
Lowest point in the Western Hemisphere
Well worth taking the drive here so you could take a picture with that iconic sign. It was interesting to see the little bit of water still out there.

The real reason we traveled to Death Valley: to reach the lowest place in North America. Good boardwalk to lead you onto the basin. Be sure to look up at the high rocks along the road to see the sign showing sea level.

This area is so big and flat in comparison to the surrounding vantage points of Death Valley. This is at sea level and appears white in spots ( which almost looks like water in the distance, it's very dry as it is full of salt flats. The landscape is incredible. You can walk out a distance to get various views.
Show less
Second badwater visit - great winter wealk

On our numerous trips to death valley NP, we reserve the badwater stop for our winter visits. It is a great feeling walking on the salt and knowing that you are in the lowest area in the U.S. Incredible 360 degree views of the above. Felt great to be able to take a nice warm walk in shorts in DV on a cold Vegas day. We made it halfway across the 'five mile trek' which we hope to allow enough time to complete on our next visit.

Warning - Be prepared for salt stains you may get on your shoes.
Show less

A place you must visit if your touring Death Valley NP.
the lowest point in North America and a nice place to get out and take a walk.
lots of people but not too crowded or hot in January.
Make sure to clean the salt off of your shoes!!!!

Come walk on the salt flats

What I thought was a paved walk out to what must have been badwater was in fact a walkway of salt! There are interpretive signs describing badwater as you leave the parking lot for the salty walk- make sure you clean off your shoes because they will have salt on them after this walk. The salt formations to the side are amazing- narrow super white salt lines outline the geometric shapes. Very different from anything I'd seen before.
Show less
Not what I would call beautiful scenery, but very interesting, especially if you read the signs explaining the history and why it is called Bad Water. You can go out and walk on the salt flats.
Great stop to take a look around. If you are in the area I highly recommend you take the time to stop here for a little.
Last stop on our dessert trip easy to walk and such an amazing place to absorb the diversity of this corner of the us
as low as you can go in North America
Cool place to see. Very desolate and eerie. Glad we stopped. The marker for sea level was very cool. Well worth the drive to get here.
Worth walking far out to see the most unspoiled formations

The lowest point on the continent is quite a sight, if you’re interested in collecting superlatives. Don’t forget to turn around while in the parking lot and look for the “sea level” sign high up on the cliff behind you. To see the hexagonal salt formations at their best, it is worth walking far out onto the basin to where they are less disturbed (the closer ones are rather trampled). Early morning and late evening/sunset can produce some dramatic lighting, especially if there is a thin layer of water over the salt crystals (not to mention that being a cooler time of day in the summer months, when the sun reflecting off the white salt can be very intense at midday.
Show less
We walked out quite a long way to get photos but honestly if you’re not up for a long walk or you’re short on time, walking 100m out from the car park gives you as good a view as walking 500m out!
We enjoyed walking out on the salt flat. Very interesting. Make sure you turn and look back for the sea level sign placed above on the rocks. Went in late November so the temp was perfect.
Neat experience...be prepared to walk. Gets dark fast, so don't make the same mistake we did and get a late start.
Not that great. Much better places in DV

This was probably my least favorite DV sight. It was crowded, it's somewhat out of the way (30 mins by car?), and there's not much to see except a desert flat. Sure, it's interesting to know you're at the lowest point in the USA, but other than that you can spare yourself a 1 hour drive and see the exact same terrain farther north near town.

Tip: look up at the rock wall above the parking lot. There's a little sign 282 feet up that indicates sea level. It's hard to spot and is pretty cool.
Show less
The lowest point in the USA

If you want to know what it’s like to be cooked in a confection oven then Badwater is a must. This is the lowest point below sea level in the USA. 114 degrees with a 20 mile per hour wind is a unique feeling. The desert landscapes are awesome and this is a must see.

No snorkeling gear needed even though you are 282 ft below sea level

Although it seems like a deserted, lifeless salt flat, there is life at Badwater. Surrounded by mountains, this flat salt plain is a fun place to play football, take a long walk and, best of all, join a ranger hike to hear about how this area has evolved. No place like it!
Show less
That's the Death Valley, the lowest and hotest point and most famous spot in this NP. Must see attraction.

Badwater is an imposing and low key sort of place all in one. Having a good understanding of the geologic forces at work adds to how impressive the location is. So stop and read the signage. Understand what you are looking at and walking across. A few tricks, get there early. The crowd won’t be there yet. You won’t be alone, but there will be a few people, not dozens. Look up for the sea level sign. Stroll out far enough that you are the furthest out. It is worth the effort.
Show less
Just to see it since we are in Death Valley

Was it impressive? Not very much. And this is the place we saw most people in Death Valley so it was really popular. Honestly the view is better from Dante's view. Should you take a picture with that below-sea-level sign? If you were lucky to have no one in the background. There was a restroom nearby and it wasn't the worst in a National Park.
Show less
Definitely a Must Visit in Death Valley!

The afternoon before, we got to see the sunset over Badwater Basin from Dante’s View and it was amazing. The next morning we drove to the Badwater Basin around 9:00am. The shadows were covering .25 mile into the basin (note for pictures), but the shade was almost completely gone by 9:45am.

The attraction is the lowest point in both North and South America. It’s cool just to visit a landmark with that distinction. The signage throughout gave a good description of the history and how the Basin formed. When you walk out on to the Basin, you’re walking on salt which accumulated there over the thousands of years earlier.

The Basin along with the mountains and blue sky offer the perfect picture opportunities. There were so many photographers with DSLR cameras there. The path goes about .6-.7 miles out but you can walk out further. There will be a lot of people out there, so it’s always good to get out early or during an off peak time.

There was a lot of parking in the parking lot along with bathrooms. It’s a 17 mile drive off the main highway to get there, but it’s mostly flat and not windy (unlike the drive to Dante’s View). This attraction is a must visit when at Death Valley!
Show less

Badwater is like a Russian doll - a white salt desert inside a gray rock salt desert inside the Death Valley. It is somewhat surreal place. The farther towards "white stuff" you walk, the more impressive it gets. However, the distance looks deceptive - the main white area is about 30+ mins away from the parking lot. Also, Badwater might be crowded and finding a parking spot could be a challenge.
Show less
At almost 90 meters below sea level this is a spot not to miss in Death NP. Walking out on the salt flat brings you another half meter lower to the lowest point (on land) in the Western Hemisphere.

You cannot go to the Grand Canyon without going to Las Vegas, and you cannot go to Las Vegas without going to Death Valley, of course. Needless to say we made these 3 stops in a week. Death Valley came in a close second against the Grand Canyon. Being able to stand on the point of the lowest elevation in North America was way too cool to pass up. In the summertime, it is one of the hottest places on Earth, so we decided on the winter, which was perfect in the mid 70s.

I, highly, recommend that you just not take a photo by the sign, but actually go and stand on the salt flats. The experience of walking on almost 200 square miles of salt on the lowest point in North America is not an opportunity that comes up every day, unless you live close by, of course. You will be 282 feet below sea level. If you look up at the mountain by the parking area, you can see the sea level point, which is marked by a sign.

The experience was amazing, to the say the least. I just wish we would have gone to the highest point in the contiguous United States, Mt. Whitney, but we could not make it in the little time we were there, since it is a two and a half hour drive just to get there. On our next trip to California, we will make it a point to, not only go to Mt. Whitney, but continue exploring the rest of Death Valley, which is huge.
Show less

At night if feels like you are in another planet, maybe the - not sure, because I have only visited Earth.
The sunset at Badwater is great and the sky gets colorful and it is very nice to take pictures and just hang with your soulmate or buddies.

This is a frequently visited place in Death Valley, expect lots of people but be sure to stop and walk out on the salt flat.
Hitting Badwater Basin and Dantes View is a good time. It's right around a mile vertical difference. Fun to look down to the bottom, and from the bottom up.
It's an amazing place! From the basin, a marker on an adjacent mountain indicates where sea level is, adding perspective to what it means being 282 feet below sea level.
walk out to the salt flats

It is very flat, easy walk, (December2017). I am guessing I walked more than a mile roundtrip Might be too hot on a summer day. Walking on white salt flats. keep going, you will see Polygons in the salt.
This was one of my favorite spots while visiting Death Valley. It was the most busiest too. We went to Death Valley during the week so not as many people as usual. Great for panoramic views and pics

This is truly one of a kind experience to be standing on salt flats. We had traveled to Death Valley during winter where days were warm and not extreme. With that being said, I couldn't imagine how unpleasant it must be during summer. Nonetheless, this one beautiful landscape!
Show less

What can be said that has not been said about the lowest place in North America. Badwater is one of the most popular sites in Death Valley. The walk area is flat and photo opportunity is not far off the path. This is just one of the many locations off Badwater Road. If you go here, don't forget to make plans to see Artists Palette, Natural Bridge, Golden Canyon, Devil's Golf Course, and the elusive Alien Head rock formation. Sunset and night photograph is the best time for photos. Bring a rubber/foam pad or plastic tarp if you plan to sit out on the salt flats to spend the day or night, it's often wet and abrasive.

This is the lowest point in north america. I was wondering if it was the hottest too because i was totally fried up by the sun.

This is the lowest point in North America, so it's certainly worth a look. The walk out from the parking lot is an easy 1/2 mile. Also, if you stop at the visitor center at Furnace Creek, you can check the times for the daily guided narration from a National Park Ranger. I LOVED that, on the face of the mountain (across the street!) there's a sign marking sea level! Really puts the place in perspective. Note: dogs, drones, & lots of other things are prohibited.
Show less

The basin is approximately 282 feet below sea level and is home to a vast expanse of white table salt. There is a boardwalk in place to avoid destruction of the many snails that live beneath the salt crust. There is a designated area for visitors to walk and view the salt basin. Quite impressive.
Show less

Visited one day in mid Nov 2017. Have been here once before 9 years ago and came back now with b/f. Salt flats seem more eroded since then due to tourism, need to walk further out now to get to larger, whiter salt expanse. Limited parking, toilet, pay station for DV passes, signs with information. Take water and sunscreen if out for any length of time, sun reflecting off salt makes area v hot. Look out for "Sea Level" sign up on cliff. Definitely worth visiting when in DV. Would considering visiting again if returning to the area.

It's an interesting place but there were other places in Death valley I liked more. It's nice to stand so low under the sea level. teh salt plain was nice to see.
The size of the salt flats is impressive. After walking quite a distance along the salt you can find yourself completely surrounded by giant plains of salt, a spectacular view.

Loved Badwater. Walking out into the salt flats was a breathtaking site. make sure to turn around and see the sea level sign as you are 282 feet below sea level and in the lowest point of the contiguous United States.
A must see! Beatiful views, amazing paths. Pretty crazy to be standing so low undet sea level. Easy walk. Kids loved looking at salt cristals.
My favourite spot in Death Valley

Badwater Basin was probably my favourite part of one and a half days spent visiting various sights in Death Valley.
I travelled in November and it wasn't overly busy. There was plenty of spaces in the car park.

It was an amazing place to visit. You can walk out into the salt flat and it's worth taking a good ten/fifteen minute walk away from the car park as you see the scenery change rapidly. A beautiful and awe inspiring place where you can catch some great photos.

There are toilets at the car park (holes in the floor pretty much) however if it is a bit too stinky for you - the main toilets in Furnace Creek are only about half hour away.

Must visit if in Death Valley.

Will Be Hot Even In Winter

OK, The valley does get cold during winter nights. But Badwater Basin is a couple of hundred feet below sea level and probably still actively dropping. But it's really the surrounding mountains that trap the daytime heat from escaping and keep it so warm. I suspect a violent earthquake someday might completely alter the weather pattern here. Meanwhile, this day, it's a treat to be able to hike all the way out onto the salt flats and explore. Like traveling to another planet. You'll see a special terrain here that you won't necessarily find in your surroundings back home. But when you arrive here, just don't snap some pics and go. Spend the day, carry lots of water, and keep walking. Bring binocs to take in the full landscape.

Badwater, which is part of Death Valley National Park is a spot everyone can and should go. If you can't walk far, no problem, parking is a breeze and there is an actual walk way.

Most of Death Valley is not easy to get to. The heat can be all consuming and if your car breaks down in the middle of no where, that can be a real drag. Badwater is patrolled, and your car will get you there, but always take water into the desert.

If you go in the summer it can get up to 115 degrees with no problem and no warning. I usually go in the Fall or Winter. But Badwater is a place I am happy to travel to in June. The heat is all encompassing, but you are safe, your car is near, you have sunscreen on and a hat and a short walk will leave you hot, but amazed at the beauty that is Death Valley.

This is the lowest point in the United States, it is about 282 feet below sea level at points. The salt flats are pretty easy to walk on and there are more colors than you would think in this hot, unforgiving place. Reds and greens and an orange you have never seen before (unless you have been to Australia) or some parts of Utah. It is just beautiful and it is a must see, at least once in your life.

The desert holds a strange, eerie beauty of its own and one that constantly calls me. To stand in this place and experience the heat, isolation and changing colours is something that everyone should do at least once!
Wow, to think we stood on the lowest spot in North America, 282 feet below sea level! I was in awe to walk out on the salt flats and look up at the mountain behind me and see the ‘sea level’ sign!
bad water cause the donkey wouldn't drink it.
AMAZING! I want to come back asap. its like being in a snow globe of a foreign World. lol I just want to come back already

This was a great stop while in the Death Valley National Park. There is a ranger to answer questions, and you can walk out for many miles on the salt flat. Be sure to take a picture of the sign far above the road marking "sea level"

Right on the highway is the parking for seeing the lowest spot in America. Take a stroll out onto the salt flats for a unique experience only found here. Look back at the rock face on the other side of the road and you will see a sign high up indicating sea level.

We visited Badwater and Dante's view on the same day and were not disappointed. The sheer scale is awe inspiring and the heat at Badwater compared to the slight chill at Dante's View just added to the whole experience.

We loved the desert and the scenery was amazing. We are already talking about a possible return trip to Death Valley for a longer stay.

1 word - stunning. You park up and walk across the salt flats which are way below sea level. Amazing scenery. Points to remember. You must remember water and sun lotion. And try to avoid the public toilet.

To get to the actual lowest point, which varies according to wind & weather, you have to walk out about 3-4 miles at a 10 degree angle NW from the parking lot and salt walkway. This is not advised when the ground is soft but can be done without damaging the flats and so this I did. Amazing to stand at the bottom of North America in complete isolation and dead silence. Having visited all 7 continents, sailed across the Atlantic, swam in 4 of the earth's 5 oceans, and circumnavigated the planet twice I add this as as important a location or "milestone" as any of the others.

Badwater are salt flats, it’s a 0.5 mile walk out on the salt flats, which is interesting but not a lot to see. The salt flats are below sea level at 282 feet below and the lowest point in the Western Hemisphere. Hot!

It is very hot even in October so don't forget to take some water with you. The path to the salty valley is easy accessible and you decide yourself how far you wanna walk to the salty field. Funny sidekick is the sign above the parking lot with "sea level" on it.

The tour buses stop here so it was crowded. We preferred devils golf course.

Many walk a little way out but if you have time you can walk further. It was hot so we didn't walk too far as we had already been out to the middle at devils golf course.

It is worth to spent an extra hour at the National Park. It is a little bit hot, but very exciting. It looks like the Moon :)
Amazing spot to stop off and check out. Blows my mind to realize that people actually traveled through and lived in this area. Awesome!!
Lowest point in the western hemisphere!

Although most of the nearby salt crystals are trodden upon by previous tourists, still a very cool salt flat. Even better if you visit Dante's Point as well, to see the same view from several thousand feet up!
The spot is the lowest point in the US but walking out into the salt flat isn't worth the trip. Nice to have a photo of you there but Devil's Golf Course is much better for viewing the salt flat.

l walked out on to the salt flats as it was something l have always wanted to do, my other half has high blood presure so he went back to the car and ran the air conditioning which l was very grateful for when l got back, could not believe how hot it was!! take plenty of water, this was our second visit to Death Valley and could not do this on the 1st as the temps were 117 degrees getting out of the car was like getting into the oven!! this time it was about 105 degrees still extremely hot to us brits but a must do so glad l did.

Very interesting stop for a view and short hike of the Salt Flats
This location is a couple hundred feet below sea level, and the major feature are the salt flats, which you don't encounter every day. Worth a short drive and a short hike.

This place lays below the sea level, i guess not many places like that exists. The Badwater basin is just a beautiful creation of mother nature and definitly worth a visit! Be sure to take water with you since the walk from the parking lot looks shorter than it is!

This is the heart of Death Valley, so don't miss it, and bring your camera. It takes about 30 minutes each way from the visitors center. Once there you can walk out onto the salt flat as far as you want to go, just allow at least 30 extra minutes. Watch the temperature forecast; morning might be the best time to visit

Death Valley was on my dad's bucket list but not, necessarily, on mine. However, I am sooo glad I took him and I would like to visit it, again, in cooler weather!
Badwater Basin was amazing--I didn't expect the area to be so expansive. In fact, the whole area is waaay larger than I ever imagined!
There are toilets available at the parking lot. You can content yourself to just look out over the area from the railings at the parking lot OR you may walk down the stairs or ramp to read the informative signings and take a few photos. You may also walk out quite a ways on the area itself. Just pay attention to the heat and distance as what length you walk out, you must also walk back.

You must to stop here just to say you’ve walked on the lowest point in North America, and walk on the expansive salt flats 282 feet below sea level! Pretty impressive!

Badwater Basin also used to have the highest recorded temperature on earth at one time measured at 134°F. Some place in Kuwait now claims a higher temp, but heck 2nd hottest is still pretty darn hot! We were there in the afternoon, and it was ONLY 108°F. Felt like a furnace! We only walked a short way past the boardwalk on to the salt flats, but many brave souls walked pretty far out. Just listen to everyone’s advice to drink and bring lots of water with you to stay hydrated. Temperatures like this can be deadly.

We visited later in September, but this park would be a great place to visit in winter when the temperatures aren’t as extreme. Death Valley is such an incredible place and is so different from any other national park. Highly recommend visiting!

I grew up in the southwest but never had a chance to visit Death Valley, all though I had always wanted to. No matter what time of year you go there are always going to be other tourists, and I was surprised to see as many as I did when I went. July is the hottest time of year down there; it was 124° when I went.
If you go, plan ahead and visit the park after dark to take photos of the stars. Bring plenty of water and be prepared for any contingencies; Death Valley is a very hostile environment.

Yes that's right - Here you will find the lowest toilets in the Western Hemisphere - FACT! ha ha . It was 50deg c here about 2pm - took water and walked out on to the salt flats . HEAT! Loved It! Great experience even for a pasty European loved the big skies and light definitely a memorable one combined with a good sound track ticked all the boxes

I wish we had more time to walk further out than we did. Very interesting signs explaining Badwater. Interesting part of Death Valley and hard to believe that once there was so much undrinkable water. A great place to take a picture of your shadow.

Beautiful drive- the walk along the river bed is awesome. A definite place to see if you are at Death Valley.

This is one of those things that you have to see you if you're at death Valley. You will be sorry later if you miss this one.

THere isn´t really much to see expect a flat sea with solid salt. But, do your reading and the place will fascinate. When you see the mountains around the big "sea" - it becomes even more interesting.Extremely hot but close to parking.
Good place to visit here at Death Valley. People were walking on the sand which looked like water. On the rocks there is a sign saying Sea Level. So this place is well worth a trip

It was hot in Summer but anyway nice to be there though for some minutes taking pictures and enjoying the scenic view.

Very nice place to visit! Don't forget to look for the water level-mark on the mountainside. Bring your own water - there's no place to buy some. Extremely hot in the summer, 122 when we were her in July.

It's amazing to see the white salt flats stretching out for miles and to turn around and see the "Sea Level" sign up on the hill behind you. I am a 68 year old, male, solo traveller from the UK who always wanted to visit Death Valley. My base was Las Vegas and I decided to fit in whatever I could in one day.
My visit was in mid-July therefore making it the hottest time of the year but also the least populated.
I had pre-hired a car from the UK (recommended) and rented a compact. A more powerful car would be useful as this was ostensibly a driving visit with a little hiking.
PREPARATION:
1 ALWAYS take plenty of water.
* TIP I bought a styrofoam cooler box and bag of ice for less than $10 from a gas station. Break up the ice and fill the box with as many 500ml bottles of water you can and take spares to replace used ones. Fewer bigger bottles tend to be too big for the box.
As signs often said "Don't just take water, DRINK it."
2 Wear a hat. For someone who doesn't normally, I soon appreciated why!
3 Put on, and take, plenty of sunscreen. Don't be a sun god/goddess, use the highest factor available. This day isn't about getting a tan.
4 Sunglasses. Again, I rarely wear them but the dry heat and oven-like winds tend to dry your eyes.
* TIP I took a "man-bag" that could hold two 500ml bottles of water, base-ball cap, sunglasses, sun lotion and although I didn't use them, eye drops.
5 Camera. I used my phone camera on many occasions but took my SLR for all the "big" photos.
* TIP Always remember to leave your phone/camera batteries on charge the night before you go.
6 Fill up with petrol (gas) before you set off and any food/snacks you may want for the day.
7 Go to the loo! There are several toilets along the way but often miles apart.

After a hearty breakfast, I set SatNav (GPS to the locals) for Shoshone (note the big, white DV set on the hill nearby) and thoroughly enjoyed the journey. From Shoshone I took SR 178 west for about 25 miles or so to the point where the road makes a right angled turn to the right.
This, effectively, is the start of my DV adventure; Badwater Road. This road is metalled and the only man-made imposition on this fabulous environment. This is a 2-way road with incredibly few other vehicles throughout the 45 mile run to Furnace Creek. THERE ARE NO SERVICES ON THIS ROAD.
After a couple of miles Ashford Mill is highlighted and I had a 10 minute walk around the remains of the mill experiencing the 110oF temperatures! There are toilets here.
Another 10 miles to Mormon Point which is effectively a viewing point and is where the valley starts to drop below sea-level.
I can't remember how many times I stopped to get out and take photos as the area is a geologists dream. The imposing Black mountains to the right and sprawling valley floor are awe-inspiring.
About 30 miles in and I reached Badwater Basin, the lowest point in the western hemisphere - and sooooooo hot. There is a designated parking area and toilets. This was quite populated with tourists and we all made our way out over the boardwalk and out across the salt pan for about 400 yards.
A few miles further and a chip-stone road cuts off to the right towards Natural Bridge Canyon. The road goes for a couple of miles before a further few miles hike to the bridge. Sadly, I realised the car was not quite up to the terrain and I did a U-turn after about a half mile. The views on the way back down were stunning though.
A further few miles and the sign for the Devils Golf Course took me off on a road to the left. The track ends in a sweeping turning point/parking area for a view of an amazing geological feature which stretches as far as the eye can see.
Yet another couple of miles ahead brings one of the highlights of the trip; Artists Drive. A one-way road through some fabulous terrain and incorporating Artists Palate and Ventifract Ridge. The loop brings you back to Badwater Road.
Just a few miles before reaching Furnace Creek is a short road up to Golden Canyon trailhead where there are toilets and a parking area. There was an opportunity for me to walk about a half mile up this picturesque canyon before the heat told me to return. I believe the hike is about 3 miles.
I inadvertently missed a few key POIs but did not feel cheated.
At Furnace Creek, Badwater Road meets SR 190 where I turned right to head back to Vegas feeling somewhat fulfilled. However, my adventure had not finished. A short way along the 190 was Zabriskie Point where more stunning views overwhelm the senses.
To top off my day's delights, I turned off on the right on a Disneyesque journey along the one-way 20 Mule Team Road.
Well, traveller, if you have bothered to read this far, you deserve to enjoy the delights of Death Valley.
So go and do it!!!

Badwater Basin looks like a frothy ocean from a distance - a great white shining expanse. As you get closer, it starts to resemble snow, crystalized and sparkling. When you finally start walking on the flats, it looks like blinding white sand. That's when you really realize that you're walking on a huge lakebed of salt. Bring water and a hat and make the trek out a ways towards the middle of the bed. There are fewer people there, and you really get to see the pristine white areas. Fair warning - it's hot. And just because it's a dry heat doesn't mean it's any better. Stay hydrated! There are restrooms at just about every tourist area in the valley, which is good, because you'll be downing the H2O all day.
